headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Eastman Chemical Co. Fourth Quarter and Year End 2000 (sic) [2009] Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] We will now turn the call over to Mr. Greg Riddle of Eastman Chemical Co. Investor Relations. Please go ahead
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Eastman Chemical Co. Fourth Quarter and Year End 2000 (sic) [2009] Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] We will now turn the call over to Mr. Greg Riddle of Eastman Chemical Co. Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly and good morning, everyone and thank you for joining us. On the call with me today are Jim Rogers, President and CEO; and Curt Espeland, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Before we begin, I'll cover three items. First, du
componenttext: Thank you, Kelly and good morning, everyone and thank you for joining us. On the call with me today are Jim Rogers, President and CEO; and Curt Espeland, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Before we begin, I'll cover three items. First, during this call, you will hear certain forward-looking statements concerning our plans and expectations for first quarter and full year 2010. Actual results could differ materially from our plans and expectations. Certain factors related to future expectations are/or will be detailed in the company's fourth quarter and full year 2009 financial results news release, on our website and in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the third quarter 2009 Form 10-Q and the Form 10-K to be filed for 2009.Second, except when otherwise indicated, all financial measures referenced in the call and in the slides accompanying the call will be non-GAAP financial measures, such as sales revenue, operating earnings and earnings per share that exclude restructuring-related items. A reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measure and other associated disclosures, including a description of the restructuring-related items are available in our fourth quarter and full year 2009 financial results news release and the tables accompanying the news release. Lastly, we've posted slides that accompany our remarks for this morning's call on our website at www.investors.eastman.com.  With that, I'll turn the call over to Jim.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. I'm going to start out on Slide 3. We're going to begin this morning by taking a minute to review a few of our major accomplishments in 2009 if I could. And 2009 was a difficult year, in man
componenttext: Thanks, Greg, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. I'm going to start out on Slide 3. We're going to begin this morning by taking a minute to review a few of our major accomplishments in 2009 if I could. And 2009 was a difficult year, in many respects, with a lot of volatility. But across our company, I think we really did an outstanding job of handling that volatility to deliver solid results. Cash generation was a priority for us, as we've mentioned throughout the year and we generated over $300 million of free cash flow. This is our best free cash flow generation since the year 2000, and Curt will give you more details in just a few minutes. Our flexible structure enabled us to respond quickly to the recession, and we reduced our costs by $200 million. And this is reflected in our earnings, both for the year and the fourth quarter. We made progress on our growth initiatives. We entered into a JV with SK for adding acetate tow capacity in Korea that serves the growing demand in Asia, and a new capacity will be up and running by the end of this quarter. We've added both new monomer and polymer capacity for our Tritan Copolyster and we're pleased with the start up there, and we're able to meet the growing demand we're seeing. And we also continued to expand our Regalite adhesive facility in the Netherlands, increasing capacity by 30% in 2009 to keep up with that demand.Despite the difficult global economic environment, our Fibers segment delivered a record earnings year, topping the previous record they set in 2008. And we did a great job on safety, something we all don't get to see that much off. But in 2009, we had our best-ever OSHA Recordable injuries' rate, reducing injuries by 40% from 2008, building on our reputation for excellence in safety. So we are well positioned to continue generating strong cash flow and to grow our core businesses.Next is an update on how we did against the corporate-outlook statements we gave you, both on our last in October and during our Investor Day in November. This is something I do on each call, and my intent is to hold us accountable for the expectations we give you. First, on full year EPS, we told you in November, we expected it to be approximately $3.50 and this implied EPS for the fourth quarter of just over $1. Excluding asset impairment and restructuring charges in both periods and other operating income in 2008, we were slightly above expectations and I'll talk more about that in a minute. We also said that the cost-reduction actions we have taken would be evident in our results, and they are. And on cash, we told you we would build on the free cash flow we had generated through nine months, including generating more than $100 million in cash from working capital for the year, and we did that from the fourth quarter.Now onto the financial results for the fourth quarter. Revenue was up slightly, as higher volumes more than offset lower selling prices. This is the first quarter we've seen positive year-over-year volume comparisons in two years since the fourth quarter of 2007. It's a sign that we are beginning to see a rebound in volume, which we expect will continue in 2010. Selling prices were down due to the global recession and decline in raw material and energy cost. Operating earnings increased significantly, mainly due to the higher volume that I mentioned, lower costs for raw materials and energy, and the cost-reduction actions that I've talked about.Moving on to the full year comparison. Sales revenue was down due both to lower prices and volumes. Prices fell largely due to lower raw material and engine costs, volumes were down due to the recession. Earnings declined but given the severity of the recession, I would say they remained pretty solid. EPS declined just under 20%, which one compared with previous recessions is a significant improvement. For example, from 2000 and 2001, our EPS declined by over 70%. The portfolio actions we have taken to strengthen our core businesses, along with the cost-reduction actions we took in '08 and '09, led to much improved earnings in this recession compared to the last one.Now to the segments, beginning with Fibers. As many of you know, Rick Johnson has led Fiber since 1996, and so he's seen the impact that recessions can have on this business. He calls Fibers, recession resistant but not recession proof. And then in 2009, Fibers' recession resistance lead to new annual record of operating earnings, topping last year's record. So it kind of begs the question, what's it take to be called recession proof? Higher selling prices were offset by lower sales volume, with the volume decline coming in the acetyl chemicals and acetate tow product lines.For tow, the decline was more in the second half of the year, due to the recession and the cigarette tax increases that were implemented in the U.S. and Europe. Looking ahead to 2010, Fibers is well positioned for another strong year. Demand should begin to rebound as the global economy recovers. We also expect our acetate tow JV with SK in Korea to start up in this quarter, and there will be some cost associated with that, as we qualify the material with our customers. So we roll it all together, we expect 2010 earnings to be somewhat below 2009 but remain very solid.Next stop is CASPI [Coatings, Adhesive, Specialty Polymers and Inks]. This is another business setting records in a very difficult economic environment. Fourth quarter with earnings of $77 million was their best fourth quarter ever. And this follows a record earnings that reported in the third quarter. Volume was up 15% in the fourth quarter due to the demand recovery, while prices declined, as I discussed earlier. For the year, operating earnings increased as lower raw material and energy cost and cost reductions more than offset lower volumes and prices. Looking forward to 2010, they have a chance to set a new record for operating earnings above the $242 million they reported in 2007. Their biggest headwind is the higher raw material and energy cost with more than 50% of the revenue in specialty product lines. The higher costs will impact their margins. Improving volume is the biggest tailwind, and we think we are in the early stages of seeing that improvement. Assuming the economic recovery continues, CASPI is set up for another strong year. Performance Chemicals Intermediates is next (sic) [Performance Chemicals and Intermediates], PCI. Operating earnings improved in the fourth quarter due to lower raw material and energy cost, higher volumes and lower cost per unit due to higher capacity utilization. For the year, operating earnings declined, primarily due to lower prices and cost related to the reconfiguration of our Texas facility during the second quarter. I would also point out that for the full year, PCI earned their cost of capital. And this is much different from their results in the last recession where in 2001, their operating earnings were only $13 million for the year.  We've talked about the actions we've taken that lift the trough in this business, and 2009 is evidence that we've been successful in this effort. Looking forward in 2010, we expect raw material and energy cost to increase, pressuring margins. But we also expect sales volume to increase, as the global economy improves. So as a result, we expect PCI operating earnings to be up versus '09, approaching $100 million.Next is Specialty Plastics. With their results in the fourth quarter, they've now placed the two successive quarters with double-digit operating earnings. Fourth quarter earnings improved, primarily due to higher sales volume, and we've consistently said the key to improvement in this business is higher volumes. Fourth quarter was the third successive quarter of volume improvement for Specialty Plastics. While demand growth is still slow for the industry overall, the number of copolyester is growing faster than the polycarbonate, acrylic and PVC, to name a few, of the things we compete against and the things we're displacing. For the full year, operating earnings declined mainly due to lower volumes and prices driven by the recession. Looking forward to 2010, as I mentioned earlier, the Tritan monomer and resin facilities are up and running, and we are pleased with the start up. And with the facilities now up and running, Specialty Plastics will have additional fixed cost though, a more than $7 million per quarter, about $30 million, for full year 2010. Some of that new from outside the company, some of that just reallocated costs within the company. And this all occurs as they ramp up their volumes. And despite these costs, we expect the operating earnings for Specialty Plastics to be around $40 million for the year and very well positioned to grow from there, going forward. Finally, Performance Polymers. In October, I said the fourth quarter was going to ugly for Performance Polymers, and it was. Loss in the quarter was due to the operational challenges we've had in South Carolina and the shutdown we took to address them, as well as depressed demand due to continued difficult market conditions. The full year loss was also due to the operational issues in Carolina, as well as lower selling prices. Clearly, we aren't happy with the results on this business. And we are taking no regrets [ph] actions to improve their performance.To remind you, we said we have two issues: Operational performance and upgrading our commercial footprint, the markets we serve. I think we can check the box for the operational. The shutdown in Carolina during the fourth quarter went well, and we've now demonstrated that it can run at full rates with Class 1 material. That's good news. Now with the progress on that, we can now address our commercial footprint and improve our mix of customers. We expect these actions will lead to a much smaller loss sequentially, and for the full year in this business.That brings me to our guidance. We're coming into 2010 with positive momentum, given our results over the last couple of quarters. We are in the early stages of volume improvement, and expect that will continue as the global economy improves. While we have a headwind of about $40 million year-over-year from the reversal of extraordinary measures to reduce cost in '09, namely the across-the-board 5% pay reduction, that we then restored in December. We will continue to benefit from the over $150 million of cost-reduction actions we've taken in other areas. And I would add that by year end, our headcount was down 2% from our spring-restructuring levels. And for 2010, we expect attrition to continue to run ahead of hiring.A headwind that we are already seeing here in January is higher raw material and energy cost, and we expect on average through the year, these costs will be higher than they were in '09. Adding all that up, we expect our first quarter EPS to be slightly above our fourth quarter EPS of $1.14, and we expect our full year 2010 EPS to be 20% above our 2009 EPS of $3.63.On top of that, we expect revenue from an asset to your [ph] license for PCI in the first half of the year, could be first or second quarter, we'll see. And we estimated it'll have about a $0.07 per share impact, positive. One last point, at our Investor Day in November, we've made the case for why we can achieve a 20% compound annual growth rate for our EPS from 2009 through a recovery, which we estimate would be in 2012. Given the results we reported in '09 and our expectations for 2010, we believe we are on track to deliver that growth. Employees throughout our company are clear on the role in delivering that EPS growth, and we are committed to making it happen. Now before I turn it over to Curt, I'd like to continue my practice of taking a minute to highlight one of Eastman's executives. In this quarter, I choose Norris Sneed, our chief Administrative Officer, who has been with the company for 31 years. Norris head's our human resource function, our information technology group, as well as manufacturing and support worldwide. He and his people are instrumental in the swift actions we took to mitigate the recession's impact over this past year. He is supported by Parker Smith in manufacturing, Keith Sturgill in IT and Ed McKenner [ph] in HR. And together, they accomplished a lot. So if you like the costings we achieved in '09, Norris is just one of the leaders who deserve the tip of our collective hat. And now I'll turn it over to Curt.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim, and good morning, everyone and thanks for your interest in Eastman Chemical Co. I'm going to start by looking at our financial highlights for the year on Slide 14. Our cash from operations of $758 million represents a terrific result in a dif
componenttext: Thanks, Jim, and good morning, everyone and thanks for your interest in Eastman Chemical Co. I'm going to start by looking at our financial highlights for the year on Slide 14. Our cash from operations of $758 million represents a terrific result in a difficult environment. Working capital was a source of cash, having been reduced by $118 million. And this in line with our projections from earlier in the year. We also generated about $125 million in positive cash flow through a change in tax-accounting method to accelerate the timing of deductions for a manufacturing repairs expense, which we discussed in the third quarter.Our cash from operations also reflected $181 million use of cash for our pension contributions of which, $150 million was made in the fourth quarter. Moving next to capital expenditures in 2009, we cut our CapEx by more than half compared with 2008. Second-half 2009 capital expenditures were at a significantly lower run rate than first after due to the completion of several growth projects.After, also, excluding our dividend of $128 million, our free cash flow was $320 million in 2009. As Jim mentioned, this is the best annual free cash flow we've generated since 2000, and is a testament to our focus on cash throughout the year. The result is that we are in a solid financial position, having reduced net debt by $256 million, and our net-debt-to-cap ratio is at 35%.Turning to Slide 15, as we continue to generate cash, we remain committed to returning cash to stockholders. In 2009, our dividend was $128 million or $1.76 per share, and our yield continues to be in the top-quartile peer companies. We pay the dividend every year, we have been a public company and management remains committed to it. In addition, during the fourth quarter, we repurchased 21 million of shares. As a result, our shares outstanding at the end of 2009 was the same as it was at the end of 2008.Going into 2010, we have $96 million remaining on our current-stock authorization, and remain committed to repurchasing shares over the coming quarters, primarily as a means to offset dilution.  We are also focused on our debt structure, which remains attractive as shown Slide 16. In the fourth quarter, we improved our position with a $250 million tenured bond at a 5.5% rate. The 5.5% rate is the best we've achieved with this tenor. The order book was six times over subscribe and the quality of the order book was outstanding. With the success of the bond offering, we decided to put a similar amount of cash to work in the quarter, making a $150 million pension contribution, and paying down our European credit facility. With this transaction, we've added a nice 2019 layer to our already attracted debt ladder, and we have funded debt or debt-like obligations that we'd otherwise have to address over the coming next few years.Looking next at cash, we put to work in our organic investments. We are beginning to see the returns from these investments we have made over the past few years. As Jim mentioned earlier, in 2009, we expanded our Regalite capacity, and we'll see the benefit of that in the CASPI segment starting in 2010. In the fourth quarter 2008, we added acetate tow capacity in the U.K., and our Fibers segment continues to benefit from that investment, which is reflected in their record 2009 results.We have taken a number of actions to transform our South Carolina PET facility and with the improved operation of the facility, we expect to see their results improved significantly in 2010. In our Tritan monomer and resin manufacturing facilities are up and running, as of the beginning of the year and we have aggressive schedule for filling out that resin facility over the next two years. This will be one of the key components that will lead to improved performance in Specialty Plastics particularly, in 2011. In 2010, we are also looking at M&A opportunities with a focus on the four areas of emphasis you see listed in Slide 18. One example of how we look at these opportunities is the venture we have with SK in Korea. To acquire SK's tow and other manufacturing assets and then to expand the tow capacity to a total of 20,000 net tons, which is about a 15% capacity addition for Eastman. This expense our footprint in a differentiated product line in a growing region. And we expect the acquisition to be completed and the capacity online by the end of the first quarter.Another example that combines two of these focus areas is the acquisition we completed a few weeks ago. We acquired a small specialty polymers manufacturing facility located near Shanghai. This is right in our sweet spot. It will support our Ensure product line and CASPI segment. Ensure is a sustainably-advantage cellulose tester used in the coatings for the packaging and consumables' markets.  We continue to explore other opportunities that also provide differentiated products and advantage feedstocks to complement our existing sustainably advantage product lines.Turning to some corporate items to assist with expectations for 2010. Starting with depreciation and amortization, which I expect to increase to just under $290 million in 2010, as we have added some new manufacturing facilities that come online. Pension expense should be slightly higher due to the lower discount rate and historical performance of our assets, mostly offset by the benefit of the pension contributions in 2009. And if we do make a pension contributions in 2010, at this point, I expect it would be less than $25 million.Our interest expense is expected to be higher, this is a combination of the lower capitalized interest, as manufacturing facilities have come online and thus reduced our capital expenditures and the new debt issue that I mentioned. The tax rate is expected to come down in 2010 to approximately 33%, which is about normal for us. Remember, the rate was higher in 2009, primarily because of the change during the second quarter in the tax accounting method to accelerate the timing and deductions for manufacturing repairs expense that I mentioned earlier, and the reversal of a tax credit related to the Beaumont, Texas facility, a project during -- which we discussed in the third quarter.Our capital expenditures for 2010 are planned to be between $250 million and $275 million. Our maintenance level is now around $200 million, and we plan to spend $50 million to $75 million on targeted-growth initiatives. This growth spending will be staged relative to the underlying economic recovery and target markets. And we remain focused on optimizing maintenance capital, much like we did in 2009. When I consider our expectations for earnings growth in 2010, plus these items, I expect our free cash flow in 2010 will be above $100 million. This includes a build in working capital due to our expectations for a higher raw material and energy cost, and higher sales revenue. We also expect to see a more normal working capital pattern for the year, including a build in working capital in the first quarter.In conclusion, Eastman is well positioned for growth in 2010 and beyond. We are evaluating all options for creating value, organic investments, M&A, share repurchases and our debt profile. We will continue to be disciplined, as we approach growth, as we've been demonstrating. Thanks again for your attention and with that, I'll turn it back over to Greg.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Curt. And this concludes our prepared remarks. Kelly, we're ready questions.
componenttext: Thanks very much, Curt. And this concludes our prepared remarks. Kelly, we're ready questions.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we will take our first question from Frank Mitsch with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, you mentioned that you were pleased with how the PET facility was operating at the end of the year. I don't think it was at that sort of level when you had the Analyst Day. Can you tell us how long that facility has been running smoothly? And why you
componenttext: Jim, you mentioned that you were pleased with how the PET facility was operating at the end of the year. I don't think it was at that sort of level when you had the Analyst Day. Can you tell us how long that facility has been running smoothly? And why you are very confident or confident that you're not going to have this sort of operational issues that you had in 2009 there?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe I'm going out on a limb because it's not like its been running for months at that level. But it has just recently, Frank, come up and demonstrated the full rate that we expect it. So all the way up to the level we wanted that, I think we've talk
componenttext: And maybe I'm going out on a limb because it's not like its been running for months at that level. But it has just recently, Frank, come up and demonstrated the full rate that we expect it. So all the way up to the level we wanted that, I think we've talked in the past about the 525,000 ton level, and we're pretty confident the plant can do that. It felt good too, that the first test quality of the product we were getting out was very, very high. So we think we've got it. Yes, the comfort level would be even higher two or three months from now when we have demonstrated we can do that, when we need to do it. And I realize, all these stuff about the operations running well, that doesn't change anything about the underlying PET market and now, how [ph] that looks. But we said we were going to take things in order, the first one is operational. And yes, I said that we got the x in the box there.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I think, I just wanted to clarify, did you said that you were expecting a smaller loss in that business for 2010, so still red ink?
componenttext: And then I think, I just wanted to clarify, did you said that you were expecting a smaller loss in that business for 2010, so still red ink?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's probably the best guess right now. And if you think about how that business usually plays out over the year, your second quarter is your best quarter. And I think that's been traditional in almost every year. But we know that first qua
componenttext: Yes, I think that's probably the best guess right now. And if you think about how that business usually plays out over the year, your second quarter is your best quarter. And I think that's been traditional in almost every year. But we know that first quarter is going to be in the red again. You know what's going on in that market. You know you had a big competitor just bring on additional capacity. And we still got a lot of work to do, upgrading that commercial footprint. So if you think we got pushed down into some of the lower value-added segments of the market when we were having operational issues, on the flip-side, that's some opportunity now that we can try and upgrade that mix.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I'd like to give you the opportunity to address the decision-making between share buyback more than just offsetting dilution versus M&A opportunities out there. How are you weighing both right now in the current marketplace?
componenttext: And I'd like to give you the opportunity to address the decision-making between share buyback more than just offsetting dilution versus M&A opportunities out there. How are you weighing both right now in the current marketplace?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're doing a little share buyback. What you'd like to do is give your acquisition program a chance to see if you can latch on to some good opportunities out there. In the long-term, that's the best way, in fact, the only way to really grow your company a
componenttext: We're doing a little share buyback. What you'd like to do is give your acquisition program a chance to see if you can latch on to some good opportunities out there. In the long-term, that's the best way, in fact, the only way to really grow your company as your organic/inorganic growth find back stock doesn't really grow your company. And if you think about long-term value creation, that's probably your highest path. And so, you would say that's higher priority to try and make acquisitions happen as well as can we drive some more product launches like this Tritan product. The issue is we're not going to be very disciplined. Curt can comment on this too if you want. But we're not seeing as many opportunities. We are looking at a few things, they're not sizable. But we're going to be patient. We don't have to do an acquisition. We don't have to spend the money. We'd like to do that,  but it's got to look really good to us if we want to let go of some of the money.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Kevin McCarthy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Kevin McCarthy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, CASPI continues to post very strong results here. I think you had commented that you expect higher volumes but possibly some margin pressure due to cost there. So netting that out, what should we expect for the trend in CASPI operating income through
componenttext: Jim, CASPI continues to post very strong results here. I think you had commented that you expect higher volumes but possibly some margin pressure due to cost there. So netting that out, what should we expect for the trend in CASPI operating income through 2010?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've got to admit it's even surprised us, sometimes here just how strong it's been. What an excellent product line, both the coatings, solvents, adhesives. I said in the remarks that they got a shot, and I think, a pretty good shot of beating the $242 mi
componenttext: We've got to admit it's even surprised us, sometimes here just how strong it's been. What an excellent product line, both the coatings, solvents, adhesives. I said in the remarks that they got a shot, and I think, a pretty good shot of beating the $242 million record year they had before. But it's just logical to expect a little pressure on the margins. Whenever you have a specialty business, you don't really price off the raws directly. Yes, you got a little help in the past when the raws came off, and now, you're getting squeezed about a little bit on the margins as raws and energy head back up. So that's kind of why we drew out there. That's just the logical expectation. But we do still see volume growth particularly around the world and the regions. And as I look at how it plays off, I imagine it will still have a pretty strong start to the year, and then we'll just see how these two forces play out, the volumes at our back and pressure on spreads in our base.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then a financial question, if I may, your net ticked up only $38 million, having injected $150 million into the pension plan and with the improvement in EBITDA, your net debt to EBITDA is just about one times right now. Jim, I know earlier in your career,
componenttext: Then a financial question, if I may, your net ticked up only $38 million, having injected $150 million into the pension plan and with the improvement in EBITDA, your net debt to EBITDA is just about one times right now. Jim, I know earlier in your career, you were used to running much different balance sheets. I'm not suggesting you want to return to that territory, but perhaps, you could comment on what you would view as the optimal leverage for Eastman's balance sheet over the next year or two, assuming an expansionary economy?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I used to be a CFO, but I moved to the second guesser role now. So my primary guesser is Curt. So let me let Curt start off on that one.
componenttext: I used to be a CFO, but I moved to the second guesser role now. So my primary guesser is Curt. So let me let Curt start off on that one.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Kevin, as you know, the way we're looking at is the key that we want to maintain as investment grade, and that investment grade status has served as well during the last 12 to 18 months. So as we look at the cash flow expectations that we have, and
componenttext: Well, Kevin, as you know, the way we're looking at is the key that we want to maintain as investment grade, and that investment grade status has served as well during the last 12 to 18 months. So as we look at the cash flow expectations that we have, and as we sized the type of investments we can make, whether that's organic or inorganic, that's going to continue to be a boundary condition. And yes, can we increase that leverage over that time period? Definitely, but it's still going to be constrained by that investment grade credit rating.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010

componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Jeff Zekauskas for JPMorgan.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the cash flow statement, you had a benefit from deferred income taxes of 1 85 for the 12 months? Do you have to pay that out relatively soon or do you hold on to some of that?
componenttext: In the cash flow statement, you had a benefit from deferred income taxes of 1 85 for the 12 months? Do you have to pay that out relatively soon or do you hold on to some of that?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll hold on to some of that. What that really reflect is two things.  One is that tax project that I mentioned earlier. What you get is you get the benefit of that program going forward. Now overtime, that lowers your depreciation expense for tax purpos
componenttext: We'll hold on to some of that. What that really reflect is two things.  One is that tax project that I mentioned earlier. What you get is you get the benefit of that program going forward. Now overtime, that lowers your depreciation expense for tax purposes, but you continue to use that same philosophy as you look at your maintenance cost in 2010 and beyond. And then second factor is just the impact of your pension contribution. And so, right now, we don't expect a large pension contribution in 2010. So you wouldn't get that benefit in 2010. But you will have future pension contributions that you'll -- as you know are very tax-efficient use of cash.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: So will you have a deferred tax use of cash next year? And if you do, how much?
componenttext: So will you have a deferred tax use of cash next year? And if you do, how much?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, right now, what I've challenged our Tax department is to continue to see a slight deferred tax benefit in 2010. We'll see how successful they are. Our target is not to have any significant cash outflow of that deferred tax item.
componenttext: No, right now, what I've challenged our Tax department is to continue to see a slight deferred tax benefit in 2010. We'll see how successful they are. Our target is not to have any significant cash outflow of that deferred tax item.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the asset impairment charge, though, 1 79, does that reflect spending that was done in the past, that's $479 million worth, that's now written down?
componenttext: And in terms of the asset impairment charge, though, 1 79, does that reflect spending that was done in the past, that's $479 million worth, that's now written down?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct. That represents the cash that was spent in 2009 and prior to this decision.
componenttext: Yes, that's correct. That represents the cash that was spent in 2009 and prior to this decision.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what was that exactly spent on?
componenttext: And what was that exactly spent on?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we spent it on was a combination. We purchased some land. We purchased some assets from Terra, some methanol assets and ammonia assets. It relates to some FEED work that we've been working on to design that project, engineering work and the like. So
componenttext: What we spent it on was a combination. We purchased some land. We purchased some assets from Terra, some methanol assets and ammonia assets. It relates to some FEED work that we've been working on to design that project, engineering work and the like. So it's those kinds of items. And now, we have a team, looking at trying to monetize as best we can in those investments. There's been a broader people who've expressed interest in it. So we're going to run a diligent process to do what we can with that asset.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, in CASPI, I. think you guys were up $45 million in EBIT. So if you had to break that out into two pieces, say, raw materials and cost reduction, how would you do that?
componenttext: And then lastly, in CASPI, I. think you guys were up $45 million in EBIT. So if you had to break that out into two pieces, say, raw materials and cost reduction, how would you do that?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know if I want to get into that business by business, Jeff. We kind of size the cost reductions for your cost the whole company. I think in Investor's Day, we said we'd expect to hold on to 100, pretty much in the bank, and there's another 50 to 6
componenttext: I don't know if I want to get into that business by business, Jeff. We kind of size the cost reductions for your cost the whole company. I think in Investor's Day, we said we'd expect to hold on to 100, pretty much in the bank, and there's another 50 to 60 that probably moves up and down were volume. We're probably going to do a little bit better than that 100 in terms of what we hold on to, mainly, because we've been able to let attrition run ahead of hiring. So labor costs will be a little better than maybe we thought when we said that. CASPI gets its fair share of that in terms of cost improvement, the typical allocation basis and then the rest would really be spread.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Jason Miner with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Jason Miner with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the PET and the IntegRex, now that you've seen it run even if for a short time, I wonder if you guys would mind revisiting the economic advantages that you think it has where it sits on the cost curve? And what your expectations are, even though the ma
componenttext: On the PET and the IntegRex, now that you've seen it run even if for a short time, I wonder if you guys would mind revisiting the economic advantages that you think it has where it sits on the cost curve? And what your expectations are, even though the market's tough?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: None of that's changed. We are over there, on the left side of the cost curve, the advantage side of the cost curve. And it's mainly driven, not just by the lower capital to get to capacity, which was significant. But also just the lower energy it takes t
componenttext: None of that's changed. We are over there, on the left side of the cost curve, the advantage side of the cost curve. And it's mainly driven, not just by the lower capital to get to capacity, which was significant. But also just the lower energy it takes to make the product, its advantage in a number of ways that build up to a nice sustainability story. So this ParaStar product, that's a product that comes out of the IntegRex processes, is just an excellent product in terms of the sustainability story, admittedly selling into a really dogging market. So I'll just give you one example. We recently gotten into the Wal-Mart supply chain where some of their private label product with this ParaStar. And one of the main reasons is it very much imports the sustainability story. So yes, it's delivering what we would want. The market is easily is bad or worse than we ever thought it would be.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think back in '06, we discussed maybe half the cash costs, do you guys have any estimate of what sort of difference between sort of conventional PET and IntegRex cash costs are?
componenttext: I think back in '06, we discussed maybe half the cash costs, do you guys have any estimate of what sort of difference between sort of conventional PET and IntegRex cash costs are?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're still in that same ballpark and what we expected several years ago. No doubt.
componenttext: I think we're still in that same ballpark and what we expected several years ago. No doubt.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: At the Investor Day, we talked. I think you guys suggested EPS in recovery could be $6 plus and gave some details with the pieces. The comments you've made this morning suggest a stronger outlook for 2010 and possibly 2012. So has your view of recovery EP
componenttext: At the Investor Day, we talked. I think you guys suggested EPS in recovery could be $6 plus and gave some details with the pieces. The comments you've made this morning suggest a stronger outlook for 2010 and possibly 2012. So has your view of recovery EPS improved? And could you just touch on maybe what elements have improved?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a little tricky because -- what we said we said when we tried to ballpark it for folks, so they could a little longer than one year is expectation is $6 off the core business when you're back to kind of the rates, pre-recession rates. So that
componenttext: Yes, that's a little tricky because -- what we said we said when we tried to ballpark it for folks, so they could a little longer than one year is expectation is $6 off the core business when you're back to kind of the rates, pre-recession rates. So that implied a volume level and implied capacity utilization probably in the low-90s. And so part of what's going through my mind is how much of this is the volume coming back a little faster. And maybe we were thinking, in terms of fourth quarter, steady, a little bit stronger, et cetera. And how much of it is the businesses that's just performing better. And in particular, the mix of products in places like CASPI, and just the acceptance of some of our specialty products, and how well they're doing competing with other materials. I guess that's really hard for me to break out. I wouldn't want people to go wildly optimistic and start moving well north of $6 just on the back of one quarter that came in. But yes, we raised guidance slightly, didn't we? Last just November, we were saying 20% higher than 350. Now we're saying 20% higher than 363. So it seems to me like we're holding on to the gains were's getting. I would call them more margin though, in terms of the $6, if you were going to move north of $6, it would be in terms of penny. The big upside is remember that it's how wise you spend that cash versus plus free cash flow generation we're going to have off of this businesses. That's what can push you well above was $6. But that's what we still have to prove.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go ahead and take our next question from P.J. Juvekar with Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go ahead and take our next question from P.J. Juvekar with Citi.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, fiber pricing held up quite well in the recession. Do you think that's because of the oligopoly of the industry that allowed you to hold pricing or is there something else going on?
componenttext: Jim, fiber pricing held up quite well in the recession. Do you think that's because of the oligopoly of the industry that allowed you to hold pricing or is there something else going on?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Quality of our products and market position and growth being positioned in the right parts of the world, taking advantage of the Asia growth market. We sell to some very, very savvy customers. So they're looking at everything. They're looking at the curre
componenttext: Quality of our products and market position and growth being positioned in the right parts of the world, taking advantage of the Asia growth market. We sell to some very, very savvy customers. So they're looking at everything. They're looking at the currency movement, remember our costs are pretty much based in dollars, others could be another cost around the world. So it's not just simple as just a handful of suppliers, because there's also just a handful of big buyers. And yes, it's a good marketplace. But we sell quality product. We compete very well. And we compete on things other than price P.J. We don't often get to talk much about it. I got to believe, we have some of the best customer service, technical service. We help our customers plant turn very, very well. And we work very closely with them to give them exactly what they need. They're in a big cash business, and little things make a huge difference for them. So just us helping them run their plats well, making the product work and their machines. That's really key to us holding on to the value we create in that business.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in PET, is there anything that's going on in that business that leads you to believe that the secular growth of PET market has slowed down?
componenttext: And in PET, is there anything that's going on in that business that leads you to believe that the secular growth of PET market has slowed down?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's what we say out there. I'm positive because I'm thinking, I remember, with such confidence, 8, 10 years ago, we talked about how fast the PET marketplace was growing. It was growing double-digit. But then it was growing high single-dig
componenttext: Yes, I think that's what we say out there. I'm positive because I'm thinking, I remember, with such confidence, 8, 10 years ago, we talked about how fast the PET marketplace was growing. It was growing double-digit. But then it was growing high single-digits, soon it was mid-single digits. And now recently in this downturn, I think we saw it flat or even off a little bit. So yes, I think the high-growth days are behind us, unless there's some other breakthrough use for the product. I think its going to start slowing down, but still wanted to -- I think it's safe to say, if you look longer term, it has as good a growth trajectory as most of the major chemicals. The issue here is the various entry are so low that the margins will always stay under pressure

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you take out the recession impact, what do you think is the secular growth right now for PET?
componenttext: If you take out the recession impact, what do you think is the secular growth right now for PET?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't spend a lot of time thinking about it P.J. I'm interested in North America. I'm interested in the specific products we make, mainly, ParaStar. We have a sustainability story. And all I'm thinking about right now is not the underlying market, I'm t
componenttext: I don't spend a lot of time thinking about it P.J. I'm interested in North America. I'm interested in the specific products we make, mainly, ParaStar. We have a sustainability story. And all I'm thinking about right now is not the underlying market, I'm thinking about how do we upgrade our position in the market because that's going to have a huge impact versus whether the underlying market growth grows at 3% or 5% or 6%. It's going to be some kind of -- W people are no better than me, but there's going to kind of mid single-digit type rate for the foreseeable future, I think, when you think globally. But again, where we our head is? Our head is we're going to upgrade our commercial footprint and market segments we sell into. And that's the best way to create value. And that's the next step in the path to run with our PET business.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Any thoughts, Jim, on disposing off U.S. PET business?
componenttext: Any thoughts, Jim, on disposing off U.S. PET business?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we've said, P.J., I think it really haven't changed. We're fairly consistent. We have a game plan. Number one game plan was to get the operational issues behind us. I'm all about creating the value that we've got there in this PET business. So I feel
componenttext: What we've said, P.J., I think it really haven't changed. We're fairly consistent. We have a game plan. Number one game plan was to get the operational issues behind us. I'm all about creating the value that we've got there in this PET business. So I feel like that one, we're pretty much done on. You always get surprised, but right now, it feels pretty good on operation. The next one, I don't want to underestimate the challenge of upgrading into better segments within the PET world. So instead of being in the sheets[ph] , you want to be more in carbonated soft drinks, for example, with their new products. here's some work involved there, and there's some time. And I think the real test, P.J., is going to come in the second quarter to see just how much our guys have been able to do about demonstrating to the markets that we've got our act together now, and we deserve our fair piece of this higher-value segment. So we're going to look at the second quarter. We're going to get through the second quarter, and see how we do. And then we'll take a look and then we said follow on is what we should do frankly in any business, just make sure you're the highest investor owner of the business. But right now, our head's all around creating value and what can we do to improve that commercial footprint.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Amy Zhang with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Amy Zhang with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: My first question is, one of your major competitors signed MOU with China to expand acetate freight and tow capacity in hopefully that several years. So you're expanding capacity in South Korea and the supply towelings to China, so what's your view on the
componenttext: My first question is, one of your major competitors signed MOU with China to expand acetate freight and tow capacity in hopefully that several years. So you're expanding capacity in South Korea and the supply towelings to China, so what's your view on the market supply/demand dollars in the medium term? And any potential impact from that potential capacity expansion from your competitors and margin profile going forward?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I'd start off by saying we're not surprised. We understand this marketplace extremely well. We know the history of the engines, we have history in fact [ph] in market in Asia. And we think its fairly well put out, very disciplined marketplace. We'
componenttext: I guess I'd start off by saying we're not surprised. We understand this marketplace extremely well. We know the history of the engines, we have history in fact [ph] in market in Asia. And we think its fairly well put out, very disciplined marketplace. We've added capacity in Korea. These are not just China but the rest Asia of Asia. Celanese is adding capacity in China again, they've done it before.  Expect that we don't see major disruption in the marketplace. We think the market will absorb that. And it may or may not be the last expansion. So there may be more to come from various players, including ourselves, in terms of meeting demand in the growing parts of the world.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: This factory raw materials cost the inflation 2010, can you provide a little bit more color in the magnitude of the cost increase for major segment? And also, you have announced a series of award[ph] -based pricing actions since last July and August, but
componenttext: This factory raw materials cost the inflation 2010, can you provide a little bit more color in the magnitude of the cost increase for major segment? And also, you have announced a series of award[ph] -based pricing actions since last July and August, but our channel tracks have showed that some of your major customers, particularly on the painting and coating side, it's back to very modest input of cost pressure on their side in the coming quarters. Can you comment on the progress you have made on your pricing? And also what your confidence level again for their pricing traction going forward with your major customers?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's kind of what we're referring to when we said we expect to have some pressure on margins. When you look at some of our specialty products like the things that go into coatings, there maybe some margin compression there. And that's where we think  we
componenttext: That's kind of what we're referring to when we said we expect to have some pressure on margins. When you look at some of our specialty products like the things that go into coatings, there maybe some margin compression there. And that's where we think  we're going to more than make up for it in volume that's why we say we think CASPI can have record year this year in 2010. But there's no doubt that the more special the product, the more likely you are to not to be able to pass along raw material increases in price, just as you can be a little sticky when it goes the other way. When you get to the more commodity products, that's where the best way to handle that is with price. And that's what the market expects. They have transparency, they look through the raw materials. You kind of have to take it specialty versus commodity when it comes to the magnitude of the move. Let me give you an anecdotal example as to why it's so hard to call. So we start the year, propane's at $1.10, and you know we use propane to feedstocks for our oxo stream particularly down in Texas. We've seen as high as -- this is just in the month of January now. We've seen as high as $1.45. I think the last time I looked, it was $1.35. Inevitably, January can be a volatile month because of the winter. But it's logical to expect raw materials and energy to move up. And it's logical to expect a little bit of the squeeze, which is what Jim implied mainly on the specialty products, like in the coatings on the margins. But overall, we kind of gave our guidance balancing the volumes, as well unexpected squeeze because of the raw materials moving up. I can't say several hundred million or something like that or '09 to 2010. We'll just have to see how volatility is.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andy, because it's not signed this year. What it is, it's a license that we wrote earlier -- it's actually the Sipchem license that we wrote earlier, and this would be the final payment as our plant gets up and running, but refers to a license tha
componenttext: Thanks, Andy, because it's not signed this year. What it is, it's a license that we wrote earlier -- it's actually the Sipchem license that we wrote earlier, and this would be the final payment as our plant gets up and running, but refers to a license that were signed a few years ago. It's just the final payment we're commenting -- we haven't had the revenue recognition event yet. And that's what we'll see whether it happens in the first or second quarter, depending on when they meet all their test.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: So there's still a possibility for you to sign some licenses this year? I mean, you're working on it?
componenttext: So there's still a possibility for you to sign some licenses this year? I mean, you're working on it?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're always working on the licensing. If you think about it, the market tends to look at stuff like that as a one-off, and it's kind of well, it's a one-time thing. But year in and year out, we have these one-time licensing deals either on the oxo side o
componenttext: We're always working on the licensing. If you think about it, the market tends to look at stuff like that as a one-off, and it's kind of well, it's a one-time thing. But year in and year out, we have these one-time licensing deals either on the oxo side or the asset deal side. And I look at it as a source of revenue. It's not huge. We've got a small licensing group. They more than pay their way. It's a well-run shop. And just kind of count on the little venues to come in when they do. So in the first half of this year, we're looking at probably an extra $0.07 on top of the number as we told you from licensing.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: You said that regarding the $6, the extent to which you get above that depends on the free cash and what you do with it. But I just want to review real quickly, when you gave that outlook that could target for 2012. For the segments, you gave a range for
componenttext: You said that regarding the $6, the extent to which you get above that depends on the free cash and what you do with it. But I just want to review real quickly, when you gave that outlook that could target for 2012. For the segments, you gave a range for each one. So for instance, cash due is 250 to 300 and PCI was 100 to 150, and I tell you the rest of them. So when you add up those ranges, the low end, you get to $6, but the high-end, you get $7.60 per earnings per share. So I understand that it's very unusual for all businesses to hit at all cylinders in exactly the same year. But in the unlikely event that, that was to occur, and you get to the high end of the range in each businesses, then the potential earnings that exists is more like $7.5. and not $6. Am  I doing the math right?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Andy. The math is what the math is. We gave you an EFO range if everything could peak out. We're just trying to be realistic, Andy. You said it yourself. What's the odds that everything clicks at the same time? And if it does, for how long does it do
componenttext: Yes, Andy. The math is what the math is. We gave you an EFO range if everything could peak out. We're just trying to be realistic, Andy. You said it yourself. What's the odds that everything clicks at the same time? And if it does, for how long does it do it?. We did our best shot. We took our best shot in giving you the ranges for each of the businesses. If things are really clicking for them, what would the high-end may be? Maybe what's the more expected level would be what gets you to the $6.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to make sure that all the other analyst were doing the math.
componenttext: I just wanted to make sure that all the other analyst were doing the math.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you're not missing anything.
componenttext: Well, you're not missing anything.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we'll go ahead and take a follow-up question with Amy Zhang with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll go ahead and take a follow-up question with Amy Zhang with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the 2012, the EPS numbers, whether that's $6 or $7.50, do you think that's a peak earnings power or just more like a recovery year earnings power?
componenttext: So the 2012, the EPS numbers, whether that's $6 or $7.50, do you think that's a peak earnings power or just more like a recovery year earnings power?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I would not call it peak. For example, that didn't have PCI hitting the peak of this cycle. I guess, when I say I wouldn't call it a peak. I'm working off the $6. I love the way Andy looks at the math. But, again, we try to be realistic on how we see
componenttext: No, I would not call it peak. For example, that didn't have PCI hitting the peak of this cycle. I guess, when I say I wouldn't call it a peak. I'm working off the $6. I love the way Andy looks at the math. But, again, we try to be realistic on how we see things, how they come together and what's likely to come together at the same time. But I certainly wouldn't call it a peak. If I'm working off a trough and most would say it's a pretty rough year, we should go back to the 30s. If I'm working at a trough in the 360s, and we can fill up these core businesses and then I really do expect to create quite a bit of value off the hundreds of millions we have in our balance sheet plus the free cash flow we should generate between now and then. It shouldn't stop at $6. But we just try to pick our point in time that we will have some credibility. If I start talking about 2015 and whatever, I don't think that's going to be all that credible. But I don't see any reason why it just peaks out at $6.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's a very helpful answer because I think the market has some nice perception about your 2012 EPS. A lot of people, I heard, they talked about throughout the year for your peak earning power, which I personally don't agree. Thanks for the class
componenttext: I think that's a very helpful answer because I think the market has some nice perception about your 2012 EPS. A lot of people, I heard, they talked about throughout the year for your peak earning power, which I personally don't agree. Thanks for the classification.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I agree with you, Amy. 2012 is probably not going to be the peak for us.
componenttext: I agree with you, Amy. 2012 is probably not going to be the peak for us.
