componenttext: Good morning

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, quick question. You mentioned raw materials as a tailwind going into next year. Can you talk about what steps you can take to offset that volatility there? Do you see opportunities to raise prices and how proactive are you going to be with prices?
componenttext: Jim, quick question. You mentioned raw materials as a tailwind going into next year. Can you talk about what steps you can take to offset that volatility there? Do you see opportunities to raise prices and how proactive are you going to be with prices?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hopefully, we’re going to be just as active with pricing as we’ve been in the past. I think that’s one of things that explains the part of our outperformance, is just how much we focus on passing through the raw material cost, et cetera. So, I don
componenttext:
Hopefully, we’re going to be just as active with pricing as we’ve been in the past. I think that’s one of things that explains the part of our outperformance, is just how much we focus on passing through the raw material cost, et cetera. So, I don’t expect that to change. I do know that the margins have been good. We all know that. They have been good. Some of our businesses maybe as not so noticeable to you, but in CASPI, the solvents for example, their margins were actually noticeably higher in solvents a year ago. So they’ve already started down in the margins.
The reason I say that is, because we think there’s other ways to offset that. So, yes, you always go to pricing, but we also think there’s additional volume to be had. As I think about it, we’ve got volume on the assets we’ve already got in place, plus we’ve told you that we’ve got a number of expansions underway. So we are going to use every tool we can to make sure what I want is each and every business to either hold their own or gain ground 2011 over 2010.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Another question. I mean when you look into the landscape into 2011, where do you see the most challenges, in terms of where in the portfolio, what segments would provide the most challenges?
componenttext: Another question. I mean when you look into the landscape into 2011, where do you see the most challenges, in terms of where in the portfolio, what segments would provide the most challenges?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s a good question, because we’re still trying to nail down our targets with the business leaders for what their plan is for next year. So I’ve been hearing about all the challenges that they are facing. Seriously, I like all our core businesses
componenttext:
That’s a good question, because we’re still trying to nail down our targets with the business leaders for what their plan is for next year. So I’ve been hearing about all the challenges that they are facing. Seriously, I like all our core businesses, what we’re down to. I mean let’s make the assumption that Performance Polymers is closed by year end, we’re left with a nice portfolio of businesses. So the challenges are pretty much the way I described. Some of the things are lower interest rates, higher pension expense, there’s just no way around that. You can just see that’s coming. Within the businesses themselves, we like the demand we’re seeing.
The biggest challenge we’ve had this year was just trying to eek enough stuff out of our pipes to meet that demand and so I expect that to continue. We’re going to need almost flawless operational performance to make sure we deliver the volumes of product that the market wants from us. Let’s see what competitors do, let’s see if they bring on much more capacity or how quickly they can get that on, how disciplined they are in recovering their costs, but overall, I can’t say enough about the portfolio of businesses that we have right now.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010

componenttext: So, in theory, should the profitability of that plant be more or less the same or the profitability of that output be more or less the same as the profitability of any other fibers output that you have over time?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, that would be an incorrect theory. We have quite a bit of integration and scale here in Kingsport, as you might expect. We consider our operations here to be just the tops. And then you have Workington and Korea and a lot depends on where the customer
componenttext: No, that would be an incorrect theory. We have quite a bit of integration and scale here in Kingsport, as you might expect. We consider our operations here to be just the tops. And then you have Workington and Korea and a lot depends on where the customers want you to ship from, et cetera. So, you could imagine the difference in cost between a U.S. mega plant, a Korean plant and a U.K. plant, but what we do is we try and optimize the three sites for serving our customers such that you ship from the one they want it from and try and maximize profit across the three.

componenttextpreview: I’m probably not going to do that because if I get into utilization rates for 2011, then I’ll start giving guidance for 2011, other than we said we’re going to be trying to drive EPS in 2011 higher than 2010. Rather than go business by business, whe
componenttext:
I’m probably not going to do that because if I get into utilization rates for 2011, then I’ll start giving guidance for 2011, other than we said we’re going to be trying to drive EPS in 2011 higher than 2010. Rather than go business by business, where we typically might talk about external use of our streams, and as you can imagine, second quarter and most of the third quarter, first two months of the third quarter, we were running high pretty much everywhere.
So, the acetyl stream typically runs quite strong for us. I gave examples for the whole company walked into the third quarter in the 90s, mid to low 90s. So that would be true for most of our streams probably. There have been times in the past where acetyls ran noticeably harder than the other streams. This year as well as we’ve been doing almost all of the streams have been running up there. So when I give numbers for the overall company, probably not all that much different by business.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about higher propane prices. Can you talk about propylene prices? Clearly, higher propylene benefits you. So what’s your confidence that propylene will stay high, especially as some new capacity is added in U.S. and in Asia?
componenttext: You talked about higher propane prices. Can you talk about propylene prices? Clearly, higher propylene benefits you. So what’s your confidence that propylene will stay high, especially as some new capacity is added in U.S. and in Asia?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I first think about the capacity near home here in the States. As we looked at that, I think that’s around 2% or 3% of the market with the guys who run that business and lady who runs that business tell me that that’s pretty much just offsetting the l
componenttext:
I first think about the capacity near home here in the States. As we looked at that, I think that’s around 2% or 3% of the market with the guys who run that business and lady who runs that business tell me that that’s pretty much just offsetting the loss you’ve had, the loss of propylene you’ve had with world cracking lighter feedstocks, etc., refineries running less. I don’t see that trend going away.
So my guess is, you can probably count on that spread between propane and propylene, because it’s only a guess, but I think as people have to go to make more propylene on demand versus just getting it the way we’ve been getting it out of the heavier feedstocks, I think you can count on that spread being there. Will it temporarily move around as capacity comes on? Yes, probably it will.
The other thing I’d like to add is, I still feel pretty good about our position. You know we are bringing a cracker back on, it’s because we think that cracker by the way has moved from fourth quarter of first quartile position just given the low shale gas prices. So I look at our position with where we thought we are going to be shutting crackers down, here we are turning around and opening one up. I know our crackers have a higher percentage propylene. This comes not only from the fact of feedstock we buy, propane, ethane, we buy higher propane mix, but it’s also just that crackers themselves produce more propylene than say what might be normal in the industry. So, all that stuff bodes well for us.
The final thing I’d like to say when people ask me about that spread is, I think we can count on it, but it doesn’t really explain the bulk of PCI’s profit. It’s really, PCI has an acetyl stream, it’s very steady, it has the olefins and oxide derivatives piece, which of course is where a lot of the spread you’re talking about gets picked up, but even there we’ve got strong derivatives. You think about the plasticizers that are growing. So we’re making part of the profit on that spread, but we’re making probably just as much profit on the derivatives, and then on top of that you got acetyls and some other things in PCI. So I think I can count on the spread, but PCI is doing a lot better than just what that spread we’d say.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Secondly, if I look at your geographic regions, you had the strongest growth in Europe, and a few other companies have shown similar trend. Do you think Europe is now building inventory maybe a few quarters behind U.S?
componenttext: Secondly, if I look at your geographic regions, you had the strongest growth in Europe, and a few other companies have shown similar trend. Do you think Europe is now building inventory maybe a few quarters behind U.S?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the inventory builds, I don’t hear people talking that much differently across regions. It’s more across markets. So I picked up the one place where I think people are actually destocking, which was displays. I can tell you that they are still havi
componenttext:
On the inventory builds, I don’t hear people talking that much differently across regions. It’s more across markets. So I picked up the one place where I think people are actually destocking, which was displays. I can tell you that they are still having trouble building inventory in a lot of adhesives markets, which you would see in our resins business in CASPI.
I think frankly, Europe just had their act together, certain parts of it. I think about how Germany has handled themselves through this recession. I think about how Eastern Europe has come back. So, I don’t think it’s just us. I think we’re benefiting from some stuff, I know that our plasticizers, non-phthalate plasticizers are doing really well over there. A few other key products, the hydrogenated hydrocarbon resins is doing really well over there, but overall I think, Europe, is maybe stronger than people gave me credit for.

componenttext: Jim, I just want to clarify for myself. One of the things you mentioned about the Specialty Plastic business, you indicated that it was up 27% on end use demand. As I understand it probably goes to some converters, is that what you mean by end use demand or did you mean that it is consumer demand as you and I would go into a store and buy something?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think a lot of it is consumer demand. Again, remember, I don’t mean to portray that we have prefect visibility looking down our supply chain, in general, when we talk about demand, we’re talking about the end use demand and when we can see inventory
componenttext: I think a lot of it is consumer demand. Again, remember, I don’t mean to portray that we have prefect visibility looking down our supply chain, in general, when we talk about demand, we’re talking about the end use demand and when we can see inventory in chains, we try and point that out. So, that’s where I mentioned displays. So, that’s one place which is going the other way. We’ve probably got some destocking going on right now in this quarter. Overall, yes, end demand has been pretty good.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would assume that part of that is displacement of traditional products, is that correct?
componenttext: I would assume that part of that is displacement of traditional products, is that correct?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. Just take an example. I pointed a couple out like the clear handle plastic bottles. Next time we go into grocery store and you look at orange juice, I’d just point it out to my wife, the difference between our product, which we can have
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. Just take an example. I pointed a couple out like the clear handle plastic bottles. Next time we go into grocery store and you look at orange juice, I’d just point it out to my wife, the difference between our product, which we can have that integrated clear handle and then the opaque bottle where you can’t even see the juice. I think we’re taking share, I think our product is taking share.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Along those same lines, in terms of overall growth, it would appear to me and maybe you don’t agree with this, please tell me, but shipments in the third quarter, if you take away Specialty Plastics, it would appear to me they’re above normal market d
componenttext: Along those same lines, in terms of overall growth, it would appear to me and maybe you don’t agree with this, please tell me, but shipments in the third quarter, if you take away Specialty Plastics, it would appear to me they’re above normal market demands. I’m just wondering how many more months or quarters do you think that Eastman could experience this stellar growth rates on a year-over-year basis? You said that your plants are full out here, you may be limited in how much growth in volume you can have next year. What are your thoughts about that?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I do think about that. In fact, I was just telling the guys here, I was in the hot tub last night looking at stars expecting that question on how to repeat and is this it and is there anything left. I already have a good answer for discussion because it
componenttext:
I do think about that. In fact, I was just telling the guys here, I was in the hot tub last night looking at stars expecting that question on how to repeat and is this it and is there anything left. I already have a good answer for discussion because it’s being asked for quite a while. I remember back when we were going through the recession and we had cut the bottom off of the trough and we only got down to about $3.60 and that surprised people and they said, well, you must’ve given up the upside.
And then we had our Investors Day and we said, we think we can do $6 in the recovery just on the core businesses alone and people were asking then you must mean nuts to peak. And then we came out and said, it looks like we’re going to go over $7, and then we said 2012, we’re looking like $8. So, I sit back and I say, what are we missing here? I think one of the things is, I think maybe it’s not as relevant anymore to talk trough and peak when you talk Eastman. I’m not saying it’s irrelevant, but maybe it’s just not as relevant because of all the changes we’ve made in our portfolio.
Now, specifically getting to do we have any juice left, I was trying to get to that earlier when I said it’s not like we ran flat up the whole year. You can go back and look at our first quarter and see that we were lower. We’re telling you now we’re coming off again in the third quarter. We’ve been running hard, but it hasn’t been perfect. We had some outages, et cetera. We know that we typically expect capacity creep each year. We’ve announced the capacity expansions we had on. So I start by thinking I got growth opportunities just in the core businesses in the existing markets, just getting more capacity online.
And then if I try and take an even longer view than that, but we can also create new businesses. As we exit PET and we change the nature of the portfolio to where we’re starting to look more special, assuming we close by end of year, we’re going to be sitting on something between $15, $17 a share of cash, depending on what else we do with our cash between now and then. That’s the way it would look today if you did nothing else. As long as you can generate cash in a business and you’re smart about how you put it work, you can continue the growth. So I hate it when people try and produce in a box and say, well, the existing business is running high utilization rates, I guess you don’t have any more juice. As long as we can generate cash, we can.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Part of my question, I’m not denying that, I totally agree with what you’re saying as far as the cash. I’m curious as to, you know, your customers, do you think they are associated in terms of their inventory levels or do you think you’ll have to
componenttext: Part of my question, I’m not denying that, I totally agree with what you’re saying as far as the cash. I’m curious as to, you know, your customers, do you think they are associated in terms of their inventory levels or do you think you’ll have to continue to run full out for another half year, for another year before they get back to normal inventory levels because it seems like your shipments have been above normal market demand in most products, there are some exceptions obviously, but just generally speaking?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, but I don’t think we just got GDP growth. I do think we got products that are gaining share and I think we are taking share. I don’t think that this has all just been inventory builds. I know in some areas they’re going to try and build, but I
componenttext: Yes, but I don’t think we just got GDP growth. I do think we got products that are gaining share and I think we are taking share. I don’t think that this has all just been inventory builds. I know in some areas they’re going to try and build, but I’ve given you other examples where they already hit their inventory levels, now they are starting to try and trim down again for year-end. It sounds somewhat conceded, but I think we’re winning in the marketplace in a number of areas and you’re seeing some very good demand. We’ll find out as we get into next year, and of course, if the whole economy turns down, so be it, but I fully expect that a number of our positions in the market will growth faster than GDP.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: One final question. Cigarette filter tow shipments in the fourth quarter, should it be higher, lower than fourth quarter a year ago or perhaps you can compare it to the third quarter?
componenttext: One final question. Cigarette filter tow shipments in the fourth quarter, should it be higher, lower than fourth quarter a year ago or perhaps you can compare it to the third quarter?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: That’s definitely going to be down from the third quarter. We set a record in the third quarter. We’ve talked about this in the past, used phrases like chunky and whatever. What it is, you got a few big customers who really try and manage their invent
componenttext: That’s definitely going to be down from the third quarter. We set a record in the third quarter. We’ve talked about this in the past, used phrases like chunky and whatever. What it is, you got a few big customers who really try and manage their inventories very well and try and think about it. So, I very much expect that shipments will be down in the fourth quarter.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010

componenttext: Okay, thanks.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010

componenttext: Hi, good morning, gentlemen.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning.
componenttext: Good morning.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: You’ve obviously been very productive over the past couple of months, so congratulations on that. Jim, just a follow up on the last question with respect to the demand out there. When I hear you say things like one of your biggest concerns is you need f
componenttext: You’ve obviously been very productive over the past couple of months, so congratulations on that. Jim, just a follow up on the last question with respect to the demand out there. When I hear you say things like one of your biggest concerns is you need flawless operations next year to meet demand and then I look at one of your key headwinds is global economic uncertainty, it’s hard for me to imagine that you really are concerned about the pace of business activity next year based on what you’re seeing right now. So based on what you are seeing right now, is this something that you are very concerned about or is it really just you never can be really certain about what’s going to happen next year, and so, therefore, you view that as a potential headwind?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Frank, it’s more of the latter. By the way, we’ve been productive all three months. It’s really just the latter. Actually I feel more confident that we’re going to avoid any kind of double dip. I don’t know that you want to take that to the bank
componenttext: Frank, it’s more of the latter. By the way, we’ve been productive all three months. It’s really just the latter. Actually I feel more confident that we’re going to avoid any kind of double dip. I don’t know that you want to take that to the bank. I’m not an economist. Just from what we see, I don’t see any signal that says that the economy is in trouble here or around the world. It’s a kind of caveat you got to throw out there because who saw the last one coming.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: All right. That’s fair enough. It’s like one of our research reports where every company we have a risk, global economic uncertainty, and it’s really just a boiler play. As I looked at the tailwinds, one of the things I didn’t see and you mentione
componenttext: All right. That’s fair enough. It’s like one of our research reports where every company we have a risk, global economic uncertainty, and it’s really just a boiler play. As I looked at the tailwinds, one of the things I didn’t see and you mentioned it during the Q&A was the restart of your propylene unit. Would you not anticipate that as we look at 2011 versus 2010 that restarting that facility would be additive to your results?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. It’s going to be sweet because, of course, we were spending the money this year and then next year we get the income.
componenttext: Absolutely. It’s going to be sweet because, of course, we were spending the money this year and then next year we get the income.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lastly, as I look at your slide of growth by geography, it almost appears to me that Greg Riddle had some fat fingers because we got a bunch of numbers repeated here, all around the 30% range. Is that an accident of nature or is that planning on your part
componenttext: Lastly, as I look at your slide of growth by geography, it almost appears to me that Greg Riddle had some fat fingers because we got a bunch of numbers repeated here, all around the 30% range. Is that an accident of nature or is that planning on your part in terms of devoting the resources?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wish it was. I wish we had that control. I’m laughing too because if you could see the earnings growth, they are all within about 3 or 4 points of each other just as well in the high 40s by the regions. Would I expect that trend to continue? No. I wou
componenttext: I wish it was. I wish we had that control. I’m laughing too because if you could see the earnings growth, they are all within about 3 or 4 points of each other just as well in the high 40s by the regions. Would I expect that trend to continue? No. I would think sooner or later Asia is going to pull away, the parts of Europe were strong is going to pull away and Latin America does well, but right now I’ll take it across the board.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: All right. Terrific.
componenttext: All right. Terrific.

componenttext: You should be running that business, because you sound just like Mark Costa. I mean the first day you had was a little later than that, so he been leaning on them and of course, he doesn’t have to lean that much, because everybody involved wants to do it faster. We see the need, but right now we’re seeing the end of 2011, and that will actually being yeomen’s work if we can get it on that fast. Yes, I would say our track record and our reputation is that whenever we get something up and running, then you start right away on debottlenecking and how do you get more pounds out of this.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right now, we’re thinking it’s probably going to be in line, it’s probably going to be low double-digit margins. One of the things we’re doing right now, obviously when you start out with something new, you’re filling up the lines and so you’r
componenttext: Right now, we’re thinking it’s probably going to be in line, it’s probably going to be low double-digit margins. One of the things we’re doing right now, obviously when you start out with something new, you’re filling up the lines and so you’re pursuing a lot of markets. As you get, let’s say, more experienced with the different market places and you start to differentiate in your markets then you can start working on your mix and start making sure that your product is going through the highest and best use to people who want to pay the most for it. So I see some improvement there over time, but right now I am looking for kind of low double digit margin to just fill it out.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Frankly, there’s always a trade up between how quickly do you fill something up and how much do you segment your market and just stay in the higher end use that they’ll pay the most for it. I think we’ve chosen that we are going to do that over time
componenttext: Frankly, there’s always a trade up between how quickly do you fill something up and how much do you segment your market and just stay in the higher end use that they’ll pay the most for it. I think we’ve chosen that we are going to do that over time.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Artavia and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On the call with me today are Jim Rogers, President and CEO; and Curt Espeland, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.Before we begin, I'll cover three items: First
componenttext:
Thank you, Artavia and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On the call with me today are Jim Rogers, President and CEO; and Curt Espeland, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Before we begin, I'll cover three items: First, during this call, you will hear certain forward-looking statements concerning our plans and expectations for fourth quarter and full year 2010. Actual results could differ materially from our plans and expectations. Certain factors related to future expectations are or will be detailed in the company's third quarter 2010 financial results news release on our website and in our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the Form 10-Q filed for second quarter 2010 and the Form 10-Q to be filed for the third quarter 2010. Second, except when otherwise indicated, all financial measures referenced in the call and in the slides accompanying the call will be non-GAAP financial measures, such as operating earnings, earnings per share and cash flows from operations that exclude restructuring charges. A reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measure and other associated disclosures, including a description of the restructuring-related items are available in our third quarter 2010 financial results news release and the tables accompanying the news release. 
Lastly, we have posted slides that accompany our remarks for this morning's call on our website at www.investors.eastman.com in the Presentations and Events section. With that, I'll turn the call over to Jim.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg, and good morning, everyone. We know it's a busy week for you, so thanks for choosing to join us. As is our normal practice, I'll begin on Slide 3 and I'll begin with a review of the outlook statements we made on the call back in July. W
componenttext:
Thank you, Greg, and good morning, everyone. We know it's a busy week for you, so thanks for choosing to join us. 
As is our normal practice, I'll begin on Slide 3 and I'll begin with a review of the outlook statements we made on the call back in July. We told you we expected the third quarter EPS would be between $1.65 and $1.75, but  then at an Investor Conference in September, I updated this guidance to a range of $2.20 to $2.30. And there were a few reasons for the increase: First, prices remained solid mainly due to higher industry capacity utilization rate for some of our key products; second, the seasonal decline in volume occurred later in the quarter than we expected really not beginning until September; and we received partial settlement of an insurance claim worth $0.19 per share in the quarter related to the outage at our Longview, Texas facility earlier in the year.
Next for full year 2010 EPS, we told you we expect it to be between $6.20 and $6.40. I updated this guidance as well in September saying we would approach $7 of EPS and now we expect to be above $7 for the year. On free cash flow, we told you we would be between $200 million and $300 million for the year, and now we expect to be over $300 million even after a $135 million pension contribution. And back in April, we told you we would review our strategic actions for the Performance Polymers business, and now you've seen our announcement earlier this week of a definitive agreement with DAK Americas to divest the PET business.
Moving next to Slide 4 and a review of our third quarter results, which were simply outstanding, if I can say that. Revenue was up 29%, volume was up 18% year-over-year largely due to improved end used demand and packaging durable goods and other markets. And while volume was up 2% sequentially, we did see a seasonal decline, but later in the quarter than we expected. 
And pricing was solid. Operating earnings at $280 million were quarterly record. The result is our second consecutive quarterly record for earnings per share. Of course this includes $0.19 a share from the partial insurance recovery. However, even without the partial insurance recovery in the third quarter, our EPS would still be a record.
While we are very pleased with our strong results both in the quarter and through nine months, we continue to be focused on increasing our EPS in 2011 compared to 2010. Even with a very high bar, we continue to set for ourselves here in 2010. 
Turning now to the segment starting with Fibers on Slide 5. Fibers continues to demonstrate the strength of their business. The result of solid operational performance and reliability, a very competitive cost position through cold gasification and long-standing deep customer relationships. Both sales revenue and operating earnings were quarterly records, and they set a record for acetate tow volume in the quarter as well. 
Acetate yarn demand is strong, and we are operating at very high capacity utilization rates there. Operating margins for the quarter and first nine months were 30% and looking at the full year, we now expect Fibers to report operating earnings of approximately $325 million, which would establish a record above their $300 million they reported in '09 and would be the sixth record year out of the last seven years.
Moving on to CASPI. They also delivered another very strong quarter sales revenue increase by 20%, reflecting both price increases and volume growth. Volume increased particularly in packaging and transportation markets in Europe and the U.S. And we also continue to benefit from our growth initiatives, including the 30% expansion of our Regalite Hydrocarbon resin capacity in 2009. 
Operating earnings increased year-over-year in the third quarter when you include $9 million from the partial insurance settlement. Otherwise, the higher raw material and energy costs were mostly offset by higher selling prices and strong volumes. 
For the year, we expect CASPI to report earnings of approximately $310 million. So to give you some perspective, their previous record year was $242 million back in 2006. So you could say they are on track to deliver a fantastic year.
Next up is PCI on Slide 7. In keeping with the theme, they had another outstanding quarter. Sales revenue increased 42% due to higher volumes and pricing. Higher volumes were due to a number of factors, including the growth in plasticizer product lines, which includes the Genovique Specialties plasticizer acquisition and strong demand in end used markets, such as industrial, chemicals, agriculture and health and wellness. Selling prices were up due to higher raw material and energy costs, including propane.
Operating earnings increased due to higher selling prices in volumes, higher capacity utilization and $12 million from the partial insurance owner. For the year, we expect PCI to report operating earnings of approximately $230 million. This compares with just $54 million for last year 2009 and the record $247 million back in 2007. 
Specialty Plastics is next, and with their strong third quarter earnings, you can clearly see the progress we've made on their growth initiatives. Sales revenue grew by 33% driven primarily by increased volume. The higher volume was due to improved end-used demand from Specialty Packaging, consumer and durable goods market. They're also benefiting from growth in the shrink film market with our Embrace copolyester and from growth in the clear handleware market. And the first 30,000 metric ton Tritan resin line is expected to be sold out before the end of the fourth quarter. 
Operating earnings increased to $31 million and their operating margin increased about 500 basis points year-over year to approximately 12%, which is in the 10% to 15% range we have targeted for them. For the year, we now expect them to approach $100 million of operating earnings on sales revenue of over $1 billion.
Moving next to PET and the transaction we announced earlier this week. Back in April, we indicated we were going to review strategic options for our PET business. A definitive agreement we announced with DAK Americas to divest the PET business related assets and the IntegRex technology begins the final phase of that process, and we expect to close the transaction by the end of the fourth quarter. 
Over the last few years, we've taken a number of no-regrets actions to improve this business, and you can see the results of that effort in the revenue and volume growth in the earnings they reported in the third quarter. In fact, the third quarter was a record volume quarter on these assets. 
We firmly believe that the South Carolina PET site is the best in the world, and this transaction reflects the progress that has been made improving the performance of the Carolina asset. So I personally want to thank the employees in Carolina that has shown tireless dedication in improving their performance of this business. And I'm very confident that DAK is well positioned to build on the progress that has been made. In a few minutes, Curt will speak more to the financial implications for Eastman of the transaction.  
Moving next to regional performance on Slide 11. The take away from the slide is probably obvious, it's the balance that we have in our revenue growth around the world. Although North America continues to be our largest region on revenue and earnings basis, we're seeing strong growth in all regions. And this balance is also reflected in regional operating earnings growth year-over-year. We view this balance as the strength of our portfolio that results in more consistent earnings. 
And that brings me to our fourth quarter guidance on Slide 11. While we expect that our sales volume will increase year-over-year, we also expect that it will decline sequentially following the normal seasonal pattern. And as I've said before, we're already starting to see that. We also expect that raw material and energy costs, in particular paraxylene, will increase, which would put pressure on operating margins. As a result, we expect fourth quarter 2010 earnings per share will be between $1.40 and $1.50, excluding the $20 million to $25 million of restructuring charges for the cost of severance programs that we announced this week. 
Combining our fourth quarter guidance with EPS from the first nine months leads to an expectation for a record year, our first year ever above $7 this year. And while we are on track to close a very strong year with a solid fourth quarter, we don't feel like we're done, which leads me to the work we've been doing since January to grow our earnings per share in 2011 versus 2010. 
We're not giving 2011 guidance today, but I did want to share some of the headwinds and tailwinds we see for next year. So we have a number of tailwinds that will be helping us, such as the Genovique acquisition, which we completed in April of this year. We'll have the benefit of our full year results from Genovique and we're on track to achieve all the synergies we expected from that. 
We'll also have the benefit of a full year of operation of our Korean facility in the Fibers business. And as we've said previously, the Korean facility came online in the first half of this year, and we expect to have qualified this material with all of our target customers by the end of the year. And our first 30,000-ton Tritan copolyester resin facility should be sold out at the end of the year, about a year ahead of the schedule, and this enables Tritan to approach breakeven in the fourth quarter, whereas in the beginning of the year, they had about $7 million a quarter of fixed costs that they had to cover. And it fell short and are in the red.
Of course, there's also headwinds. Sustainable global economic recovery is by no means guarantee to any others. There's going to be volatility in our main raw material and energy cost for propane, paraxylene, wood pulp, coal and other raw materials. That's always a risk. And increases to our corporate cost structure, in particular things like the pension expenses due to the low interest rates and costs related to the capacity additions we are making are also a headwind.
So recognizing these and other tailwinds and headwinds, our objective is to make 2011 EPS greater than 2010, and we take this very seriously.
Now one of the parts I like, I get to turn to, what I call, the executive spotlight. And I'm going to continue the practice of signing the spotlight on an of the company that I believe had stellar performance during the quarter. 
And given the announcement of signing a definitive agreement to sell our Performance Polymers business, it should come as no surprise that I want to give credit to our corporate development team. I mentioned earlier, the employees in the Performance Polymers business and their contribution to this outcome. But specific to the transaction was Curt Espeland's team led by Damon Warmack and Mohit Bhalla, who did an exceptional job. Many of you know Damon from his time leaving our CASPI business and our PCI business, and he continues to excel in his current role of Strategy and Corporate Development. Mohit Bhalla had investment banking experience before he came to Eastman, and we're now benefiting from his deal savvy as shown by this transaction. Of course, they're supported by a strong team in Corporate Development, Finance and Legal. When I put this outcome together, the sale of our Performance Polymers business with its successful acquisition at Genovique, I have a high degree of confidence that we can execute our inorganic growth strategy to grow the company. 
So thanks again to Curt's team in Corporate Development, and now I'll turn it over to Curt.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim and good morning, everyone. I want to start with our 2010 free cash flow expectations on Slide 14. In the third quarter we generated $316 million in operating cash flows and $228 million in free cash flow. This continues to demonstrate our str
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim and good morning, everyone. I want to start with our 2010 free cash flow expectations on Slide 14. In the third quarter we generated $316 million in operating cash flows and $228 million in free cash flow. This continues to demonstrate our strong earnings performance is translating into significant cash generation. 
From a working capital standpoint, we are seeing good discipline across the company. The majority of the increase in working capital to date has been in receivables, reflecting the improved sales revenue and the change in accounts receivable securitization program that I mentioned earlier in the year. 
In fourth quarter we expect to generate cash from working capital, which is our normal seasonal pattern. Given our strong cash flow generation this year, we have decided to contribute an additional $100 million to our U.S.-defined benefit pension plan beyond the $35 million already made. We are, in essence, accelerating a contribution that might otherwise need to be made next year due to the anticipated low level and discount rate at the year end. This is also that a tax efficient use of cash will help offset some of the expected pension headwinds in 2011. 
Our capital expenditures did ramp up in the third quarter, but not to the degree anticipated. Again, this reflects good stewardship of capital dollars in the halls of Eastman. We expect our capital expenditures will be approaching $100 million in the fourth quarter. This reflects our plans to expand capacity in a number of areas that I'll speak to in a minute.
Putting this together, our estimated capital expenditures will be approximately $225 million in 2010. Even with the increase in pension contribution, we continue to expect our free cash flow will be over $300 million for the year. And as a reminder, our free cash flow expectation is net of our strong dividend.
A question we often get, and I expect some of you may have this morning is how we're going to put this cash to work. An answer in that question, it is helpful to see how we have allocated cash in the first nine months of 2010 across the four buckets we've talked previously here on Slide 15. 
In the build bucket, we have spent $133 million of capital expenditures. And as I just mentioned, we expect that ramp-up will occur in fourth quarter and into 2011. I'll talk more about this capacity addition shortly. 
In the joint ventures and acquisitions bucket, we completed the acquisition of Genovique back in May. And in March, we started up the acetate tow facility in Korea that we had acquired from SK. Back in January, we acquired a small specialty polymers manufacturing facility in China to support CASPI segment. 
And our Specialty Plastics business recently entered into a small cellulose diacetate compounding joint venture with a manufacturer, who is also in China. We are looking at several small to medium-sized opportunities that would be a good strategic fit for Eastman. We need bid/ask spreads to tighten some to ensure such transactions provide good value for our shareholders. In addition, we anticipate better quality asset should come in the market as companies become more confident with 2011 economic environment. Until then, we'll continue to be active, but also be patient and disciplined.
In the equity bucket, we have repurchased year-to-date $68 million in shares outstanding primarily to offset dilution. I would anticipate the level of share repurchases to increase in fourth quarter 2010 and going into 2011 in part to offset the additional dilutive effect of stock options in the money resulting from our share price increase or the actual issuance of shares upon exercise of such options. 
And one other matter related to comp-related programs, for tax planning reasons, we are aware that participants in our deferred comp plan are considering early withdrawal of a portion of their deferred pay as allowed under the plan. This could result in a cash payment in the fourth quarter or up to $35 million to participants, including executive officers. Any executive officers who received early pay out of the amount in the Phantom stock account of the deferred comp plan would complete a Form 4 filing even though it would not involve shares of Eastman stock.
Lastly in the debt and long term liabilities bucket, we will continue to be opportunistic as market conditions evolve. So going forward, you would expect us to continue to be disciplined in allocating cash of both the best opportunities in each of these buckets just as we demonstrated in the first nine months.
Turning next to the announced capacity additions on Slide 16. The common characteristic of each of these capacity additions is that they are driven by strong demand growth in very attractive markets where Eastman has a competitive advantage. And they all have attractive returns well above our cost of capital. 
Starting with the CHDM capacity edition. CHDM is the monomer used in the manufacture of copolyester for the Specialty Plastics segment. As a reminder Specialty Plastics volume has increased 37% for the first nine months and was at a record level in the second quarter after increasing in sequentially for six straight quarters. We expect the 25% increase in CHDM capacity to be online in two phases with the first to mid-2011 and the second in 2012 to support continued strong growth expectations with core copolyesters.
Next is the Tritan copolyester capacity edition. At the end of 2009, we started up a Tritan monomer facility to support two 30,000 metric ton Tritan resin facilities and then started up the first of those resin facilities. Each resin facility supports new revenue in excess of the $100 million. We had expected to sell out the first resin facility by the end of 2011, but demand has been stronger than we expected, thus we expect it will be now sold out by the end of fourth quarter. As a result, we are adding the second Tritan resin facility and expect that would be online around the end of 2011. 
Also on the Specialty Plastics cellulose triacetate or CTA, which is used in the LCD industry for the manufacture of polarizer films. We had plans back in 2009 to expand CTA capacity that was put on hold due to the recession.
In 2010, we have seen a nice return in demand for CTA and it is expected to be very strong over the next several years with a compound annual growth rate of better than 10%. As a result, we are expanding our CTA capacity by approximately 70% with a new capacity expected to be online in first quarter 2012. We're also expanding our 2-EH capacity along at our Longview, Texas site. This expansion support our growth efforts in the plasticizers market, particularly with our non-phthalate plasticizers, which are expected to have about a 7% compound annual growth rate for North America and Europe for the next five years. 2-EH is also used as an additive for fuels and lube oils.
We have a small debottleneck that will be completed in the fourth quarter this year and an additional expansion expected to be online in mid-2012. 
Lastly, we're once again expanding our Regalite hydrocarbon resin capacity. Regalite is used as a raw material for hot melt and pressure-sensitive adhesives and was also used in non-woven products, such as disposable diapers. We expanded our Middleburg facility 3x since 2006. This expansion will add approximately 20% to current capacity and is expected to be aligned the second half of 2011. Again, these are good uses of cash and will benefit earnings going into 2012.
Next I'll briefly cover the expected financial impact of the PET transaction. First, just the piggyback off of Jim, I'd like to add my thanks to the corporate development team and the others who have been working on this transaction over the last several months. 
As I've said in the past, whoever wants to be the market leader in PET North America would want our IntegRex technology in the South Carolina facility. This has proven to be the case and should provide or be a win-win transaction for both parties. We expect total proceeds will be $600 million before transaction costs with the final price subject to working capital adjustments at closing. The transaction will also result in approximately $100 million of payment of taxes to be made shortly after closing. The timing of the payment will depend on the date of the closing so it could be the fourth quarter or could be in the first quarter of 2011. We still expect overall transaction to close before the end of this year. 
As you know, all tax payments are reflected as cash flows from operations, and therefore will impact our free cash flow where made. In addition, we have approved our restructuring plan to address the indirect cost associated with the Performance Polymers business segment. We expect to recognize a charge between $20 million and $25 million in the fourth quarter for severance cost associated with this claim. Regarding the potential EPS impact of the transaction on our fourth quarter results, our forecast for Performance Polymers segment results, excluding corporate costs that have previously allocated to the business, is near breakeven. We, therefore, expect that reporting the Performance Polymers results as discontinued operations will have a minimal impact on earnings from continuing operations for the company in the fourth quarter.
Lastly, I'm very pleased to invite you to join us for our 2011 Investment Day in New York City on March 1. We're holding it at Sentry Center, which is conveniently located in Midtown on Third Avenue between 45th and 46th streets. Like our last Investor Day, there will be a presentation from our senior management, and we'll update you on our growth strategies. I look forward to seeing you there, and with that, I'll turn it back over to Greg.

componenttext: Which by the way -- I'll just jump to it. When I look at, do we have juice left? We did run really hard during the middle of the year, but on the shoulders capacity utilization still wasn't at peak. So there's still some more room to go.

componenttext: Our next question is from Kevin McCarthy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, now that you've got some visibility into timing and magnitude of the proceeds from the PET divestiture, what are your latest thoughts with regard to potential acceleration of share repurchases and/or initiating a dividend increase?
componenttext: Jim, now that you've got some visibility into timing and magnitude of the proceeds from the PET divestiture, what are your latest thoughts with regard to potential acceleration of share repurchases and/or initiating a dividend increase?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know it's on everybody's minds. I mean what we've said before, I won't drag you through all the buckets again, but you know we want to use all of them. But in the owners bucket with equity, we talked about keeping up with the share creep in terms of dil
componenttext: I know it's on everybody's minds. I mean what we've said before, I won't drag you through all the buckets again, but you know we want to use all of them. But in the owners bucket with equity, we talked about keeping up with the share creep in terms of dilution that comes from options, et cetera. And we're, actually, were a little bit ahead of it. And then of course, when you set a record price, basically all your options go in the money. And so we need to pick up the pace there on the share buyback just to offset dilution. Beyond that, we do have the flexibility to buyback beyond just offsetting dilution, if that looks like our best alternative. But remember, I'm always comparing it to what we see in the other bucket. So we're trying to play that a bit by ear and see if we got better growth opportunities. But you can expect our share buybacks will pick up, first of all, just to keep up with the new dilution numbers. And then if we want, we could go a little beyond that. On the dividend, of course, I always beg off because that's a board decision. We pay a healthy dividend and that discussion really isn't right at this time. But I guess the next time the board looks at it is in December. And we obviously think that returning cash to shareholders is a very valid use of cash and we look at the dividend and we look at share buybacks as our ways to do that. But we'll just have to wait and see what comes on that score.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, with regard to the 4Q comments, it would seem that you're sequential guidance is arguably somewhat conservative relative to the sequential patterns you would have had, 3Q into 4Q in years like 2006 and 2007, kind of pre-credit crisis. So in that cont
componenttext: Jim, with regard to the 4Q comments, it would seem that you're sequential guidance is arguably somewhat conservative relative to the sequential patterns you would have had, 3Q into 4Q in years like 2006 and 2007, kind of pre-credit crisis. So in that context, are you seeing a more pronounced seasonal decline in any of your businesses that you feel would create that kind of pressure? Or is there an element of conservatism in setting the bar here?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually we're trying to call it pretty close and we're getting better, by the way. I know we've missed on the bottom side. But in terms of expectations, we always seem to do noticeably better than we say, but this last time when you come in at 233 and we
componenttext: Actually we're trying to call it pretty close and we're getting better, by the way. I know we've missed on the bottom side. But in terms of expectations, we always seem to do noticeably better than we say, but this last time when you come in at 233 and we quote 220 to 230 during the quarter, I feel like we're getting better on that. I don't see anything all that unusual. There is some inventory destocking in some Specialty Plastics markets like in displays, but when I went back and looked at that the typical seasonal drop, I looked at 2005 and I can't -- there was a couple of other years. And to get this kind of drop, especially when you remember to back out the insurance from the third quarter when you're just comparing third and fourth, it doesn't feel that out of whack to me from a seasonal point of view.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kevin, I might add just -- Jim highlighted in the third quarter, the seasonality. We didn't see the drop in seasonality until later in the quarter, so that makes the fourth quarter drop a little more pronounced, but the seasonality is not out of the ordin
componenttext: Kevin, I might add just -- Jim highlighted in the third quarter, the seasonality. We didn't see the drop in seasonality until later in the quarter, so that makes the fourth quarter drop a little more pronounced, but the seasonality is not out of the ordinary. And as Jim mentioned, the insurance settlement in the third quarter won't materially repeat in the fourth quarter.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: But it's still been going to roll up to a great year. And I think if we do 140 to 150, that's got to be close to a record fourth quarter as well.
componenttext: But it's still been going to roll up to a great year. And I think if we do 140 to 150, that's got to be close to a record fourth quarter as well.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to Specialty Plastics, I think about the $10 million sequential increase in operating profit. Obviously, I would imagine you've got a diminished drag from Tritan, but are there some other factors at work there and explaining the very strong re
componenttext: With regard to Specialty Plastics, I think about the $10 million sequential increase in operating profit. Obviously, I would imagine you've got a diminished drag from Tritan, but are there some other factors at work there and explaining the very strong results in the quarter in [indiscernible]?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Probably a couple of things. I mean I don't want to take anything away from the Specialty Plastics. The copolyester did very well, the cellulose esters did extremely well. We also had a case where in a more Specialty business, you're trying to make your p
componenttext: Probably a couple of things. I mean I don't want to take anything away from the Specialty Plastics. The copolyester did very well, the cellulose esters did extremely well. We also had a case where in a more Specialty business, you're trying to make your pricing in raws. You're always trying to cover your raws with price, but you can't be real smooth about it. So one of the things we see is, I don't think paraxylene moved up as much as perhaps we've gotten price. And now as you go into the fourth quarter with paraxylene moving up, you'll probably give a little of that back. So I wouldn't read any huge trends into it. It's probably more the timing of pricing versus raws. But I can just tell you within Specialty Plastics, everything seems to be performing very well.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from  Edlain Rodriguez with Gleacher & Company.
componenttext: Your next question is from  Edlain Rodriguez with Gleacher & Company.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, quick question. You mentioned raw materials as a tailwind going into next year. Can you tell what steps we can take to offset that volatility there? I mean do you see opportunities to raise prices and how proactive are you going to be with prices?
componenttext: Jim, quick question. You mentioned raw materials as a tailwind going into next year. Can you tell what steps we can take to offset that volatility there? I mean do you see opportunities to raise prices and how proactive are you going to be with prices?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hopefully, we're going to be just as active with pricing as we've been in the past. I mean I think that's one of the things that explains a part of our outperformance is just how much we focus on passing through the raw material costs, et cetera. I don't
componenttext: Hopefully, we're going to be just as active with pricing as we've been in the past. I mean I think that's one of the things that explains a part of our outperformance is just how much we focus on passing through the raw material costs, et cetera. I don't expect that to change. I do know that the margins have been good, we all know that. They've been good. Some of our businesses, maybe it's not so noticeable to you, but in CASPI, the solvents, for example, their margins were actually noticeably higher in solvents a year ago. So they've already started down in the margins and the reason I say that is because we think there's other ways to offset that. So yes, you always go with pricing, but we also think there's additional volume to be had. And as I think about it, we've got volume on the assets we've already got in place, plus we've told you that we've got a number of expansions underway. So we're going to use every tool we can to make sure that what I want is each and every business to either hold their own or gain ground in 2011 over 2010.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: When we look into the landscape in 2011, where do you see the most challenges? I mean in terms of where in the portfolio? What segments would provide the most challenges?
componenttext: When we look into the landscape in 2011, where do you see the most challenges? I mean in terms of where in the portfolio? What segments would provide the most challenges?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a good question because we're still trying to nail down our targets with the business leaders for what their plan is for next year. So I've been hearing about all their challenges that they're facing. Seriously, I like all our core businesses, what
componenttext: That's a good question because we're still trying to nail down our targets with the business leaders for what their plan is for next year. So I've been hearing about all their challenges that they're facing. Seriously, I like all our core businesses, what we're down to. I mean let's make the assumption that Performance Polymers is closed by year end. We're left with a nice portfolio of businesses. So the challenges are pretty much the way I described. Some of the things are lower interest rates, higher pension expense. There's just no way around that. You can just see that's coming. Within the businesses themselves, we like the demand we're seeing. The biggest challenge we've had this year was just trying to eek enough stuff out of our pipes to meet that demand, and so I expect that to continue. We're going to need almost flawless operational performance to make sure we deliver the volumes of product that the market wants from us. Let's see what competitors do. Let's see if they bring on much more capacity or how quickly they can get that on, how disciplined they are and recovering their costs. But over all I can't say enough about this portfolio of businesses that we have right now.

componenttext: I try not to look plant-by-plant, even if I do, I try not to talk plant-by-plant. I don't think it's been a big -- it's not going to be a big add. It's probably more like a breakeven for this year, I would guess. We did get some volume out of it. We're qualifying with customers as we've said. But the real benefit will come in next year.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: So in theory, should the profitability of that plant be more or less the same? Or the profitability of that output be more or less the same as the profitability of any other Fibers output that you have over time?
componenttext: So in theory, should the profitability of that plant be more or less the same? Or the profitability of that output be more or less the same as the profitability of any other Fibers output that you have over time?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, that would be an incorrect theory. We have quite a bit of integration and scale here in Kingsport, so as you might expect, we consider our operations here to be just the tops. Then you have Workington in Korea and a lot depends on where the customers
componenttext: No, that would be an incorrect theory. We have quite a bit of integration and scale here in Kingsport, so as you might expect, we consider our operations here to be just the tops. Then you have Workington in Korea and a lot depends on where the customers want you to ship from, et cetera. So you could kind of imagine the difference in cost between a U.S. mega plant, a Korean plant and a U.K. plant, but what we do is we try and optimize the three sites for serving our customers, such that you ship from the ones they want it from and try and maximize profit across the three.

componenttext: It's probably a difference of roughly now, $7 million in the whole at the beginning of the year to a breakeven at the end of the year, which by the way, when you got your monomer plant, which is the sizable capital investment running at 50%, you can break even. That's not too bad.

componenttext: And if I could just ask sort of, I guess, probably two elementary questions. So you brought up Triton, it's been a very successful product. You were losing $7 million a quarter in the beginning of the year and we' now breakeven. Like why is this good? Shouldn't we be making a lot of money in Triton?

componenttext: The monomer plant's running at 50%, Jeff. So at anytime you have a big capital expenditure that's running at 50% and you break even, that's probably going to bode well for when that thing runs flat out.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010

componenttext: This is actually Luisa Hermann in for Bob. I'm wondering you touched on a capacity utilizations earlier. Can you just give us a little bit of color on what you see in terms of capacity utilization across the businesses versus the industry in the fourth quarter? And then also what you're seeing or what your expectations are for 2011?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I get into utilization rates for 2011, then I start giving guidance for 2011 other than we said we're going to be trying to drive the EPS higher than 2010. Rather than go business-by-business, just what we typically might talk about external use of our
componenttext: If I get into utilization rates for 2011, then I start giving guidance for 2011 other than we said we're going to be trying to drive the EPS higher than 2010. Rather than go business-by-business, just what we typically might talk about external use of our streams and as you can imagine in the second quarter and most of the third quarter, first two months of the third quarter, we were running high pretty much everywhere. So the acetyl stream typically runs quite strong for us. I gave examples for the whole company who walked in to the third quarter in the 90s, mid to low-90s. And so that would be true for most of our streams probably. And there's been times in the past where acetyls ran noticeably harder than the other streams, but this year as well as we've been doing, almost all the streams have been running up there. So when I give numbers for the overall companies, probably not all that much different by business.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from P.J. Juvekar with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question is from P.J. Juvekar with Citi.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about higher propane prices. Can you talk about propylene prices? Clearly higher propylene benefits you. What's your confidence that propylene will stay high, especially as some new capacity is added in U.S. and in Asia?
componenttext: You talked about higher propane prices. Can you talk about propylene prices? Clearly higher propylene benefits you. What's your confidence that propylene will stay high, especially as some new capacity is added in U.S. and in Asia?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I first think about the capacity near home here in the States. And as we looked at that, I think that's around 2% or 3% of the market with the guys who run that business and lady who runs that business tell me that, that's pretty much just offsetting the
componenttext: I first think about the capacity near home here in the States. And as we looked at that, I think that's around 2% or 3% of the market with the guys who run that business and lady who runs that business tell me that, that's pretty much just offsetting the loss you've had, the loss of propylene you've had with the world-cracking lighter feedstocks, et cetera. So refinery's running less. And I don't see that trend going away. So my guess is you can probably count on that spread between propane and propylene. Of course, it's only a guess, but I think those people have to go to make more propylene on demand versus just getting it the way we've been getting it out of the heavier feedstocks, I think. I think you can count on that spread being there. Will it temporarily move around as capacity comes on? Yes, it probably will. But the other thing I'd like to add is I still feel pretty good about our position.  I mean you know we're bringing a cracker back on, it's because we think that cracker, by the way, has moved from fourth quarter of first quartile cost position just given the low shale gas prices. So I look at our position with where we thought we were going to be shutting crackers down, here we are turning around, opening one up. I know our crackers have a higher percentage propylene, comes not only from the fact that feedstock would buy propane. Ethane would buy a higher propane mix, but it's also just the crackers themselves produced more propylene than say, what might be normal in the industry. So all that stuff bodes well for us. And the final thing I'd like to say when people asked me  about that spread is, I think we can count on it, but it doesn't really explain the bulk of PCIs profit. It's really, PCI has an acetyl stream that's very steady. It has the olefins and oxide derivatives piece, which of course is where a lot of the spread you're talking about gets picked up. But even there, we got strong derivatives. You think about the plasticizers that are growing so we're making part of the profit on that spread, but we're making probably just as much profit on the derivatives. And then on top of that, you got acetyls and some other things in PCI. So I think I can count on this spread, but PCI is doing a lot better than just what that spread would say.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Secondly, if I look at your geographic regions, you had the strongest in Europe and a few other companies have shown similar strength. Do you think Europe is now building inventory maybe a few quarters behind U.S.?
componenttext: Secondly, if I look at your geographic regions, you had the strongest in Europe and a few other companies have shown similar strength. Do you think Europe is now building inventory maybe a few quarters behind U.S.?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the inventory builds, I don't know, I don't hear people talking that much differently across regions. It's more across markets. So I think that the one place where I think, people are actually destocking, which was displays, I can tell you that they're
componenttext: On the inventory builds, I don't know, I don't hear people talking that much differently across regions. It's more across markets. So I think that the one place where I think, people are actually destocking, which was displays, I can tell you that they're still having trouble building inventory in a lot of the adhesives markets, which you would see in our Resins business in CASPI. I think, frankly, Europe just had their act together, certain parts of it. I think about how Germany has handled themselves through this recession. I think about how Eastern Europe has come back. So I don't think it's just us. I think we're benefiting from some stuff. I know that our plasticizers, non-phthalate plasticizers' doing really well over there. A few other key products, the hydrogenated hydrocarbon resins' doing really well over there. But overall, I think Europe is maybe stronger than people give them credit for.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, I just want to clarify myself. One of the things you mentioned about the Specialty Plastics business, you indicated that it was up 27% on end-use demand. Part of that business, as I understand it, probably goes to something converters, is that what y
componenttext: Jim, I just want to clarify myself. One of the things you mentioned about the Specialty Plastics business, you indicated that it was up 27% on end-use demand. Part of that business, as I understand it, probably goes to something converters, is that what you mean by end-used demand? Or do you mean that it's consumer demand as you and I were going to a store and buy something?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think a lot of it's consumer demand. Again remember, I don't mean to portray that we have perfect visibility looking down our supply chain. But in general, when we talk about demand, we're talking about the end use demand and what we can see inventory i
componenttext: I think a lot of it's consumer demand. Again remember, I don't mean to portray that we have perfect visibility looking down our supply chain. But in general, when we talk about demand, we're talking about the end use demand and what we can see inventory in the chains, we try and point that out because that's where I mentioned displays. That's one place where it's going, the other way where you've probably got some destocking going on right now in this quarter. But overall, yes, end demand has been pretty good.

componenttext: Absolutely, and just take an example. I even pointed a couple out, like the clear handle plastic bottles.
